title: How long does it take you to write one page? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have no idea how long it takes me to write a page, Addie. I just start at the beginning and keep going until I’m finished. That might take days, hours, or minutes. I’ll explain what I mean, but first let me note the time so we can see how long this page takes. I drafted it last night in a little under fifteen minutes. Now editing starting at 9:06 AM. And the answers are: If you mean how long does it take me to think about my answers to questions, that can be anywhere from a few seconds to several days. Right now, for example, I’ve got eleven draft answers waiting to be posted on Quora, but I haven’t submitted any of them yet. I think I’ve decided that some of them didn’t have to be written in the first place. I’m calling all such posts ‘think-abouts.’If you mean how long does it take me to get a draft on paper, the answer is “Not long at all,” since I type almost as quickly as I can talk.If you’re asking how long it takes me to write a page of final copy, then the answer really is “I don’t know.” That’s not only because I’ve never timed myself; it’s also because it depends on what I’m writing.THAT WAS THE FIRST ANSWER. Here’s the second one if — Oh, #%^! Enter the dreaded technical problem. I want to get rid of that ‘a,’ but the computer isn’t letting me. I’m taking time out here: two for snarling and wishing I could replace this laptop with a new one and eight to stretch and get another cup of coffee.)ANSWER #2: ZERO TO FINISH LINE\ (9:26 AM) When might writing a single page take several hours? When I haven’t clarified for myself exactly what I want to say. At times like that, I just keep writing in order to discover what I was aiming at. It always turns up, sooner or later.When what I’m writing requires frequent stops to fact-check, to look up book titles, medical terms, or such things as a list of factors making breast x rays so hard to interpret. (I’m not a physician, but I’ve learned a lot during my 18 years as a volunteer breast cancer advocate. )When I’ve got to be extra-careful about how I phrase something. Words used carelessly can do so much harm that, especially when it comes to women with b.c., I feel obligated to comb through my posts, finding and replacing words that’re little ‘time bombs’ — words that linger in the mind and then, several hours latr, explode — with safer, less scary words. Ok, it is now 10:27, which is abt one hour from “FINAL DRAFT at 9:26.” Subtract, say, 15? 20? mins for coffee, some stretching, two incoming phone calls at abt three minutes and — okay, three incoming calls, but this one didn’t even take a minute. Oh, and a bathroom break. And three for the technical annoyance. And a wrong number just now. And now a long incoming text …hang on… Sigh. Let’s use 9:26 to 10:27, ’cause between the phone calls, texts, and the doorbell a moment ago, it suddenly became 11:01. Some days are just like that. Plz do the math. What’ve we got, start to finish, in terms of time? Somewhere between thirty and forty-five minutes? More? Less?  NB: I’m sure others can write their answers in less than half the time it has taken me, so please don’t assume that it’ll take you as long as it takes me to turn out a page of text. Warmly, cb

I hate answers that begin with “it depends” but it depends. If I’m writing fiction, and I hit a spot in the book where the plot is clear, it can take about 15 minutes because I’ve been writing it in my head for some time. On these days, I can write about 3,000 words over a three to four hour stint. I’m a slow (and bad) typist and I try to edit as I write. My first drafts are clean and, as one of my critique partners pointed out, “Better than most people’s fourth drafts” and I don’t revise much. If I’m writing something like a press release, it may take half-an-hour. Part of my learning to write stems from the years I spent in the print media, as a reporter and editor at such dailies as the San Jose Mercury-News.. I learned to frame a story quickly and write fast so organizing my thoughts and developing a linear flow comes easily to me. I think everyone should work under a deadline at some point because it forces you to be cogent and careful with words.
